verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 1:1
verses.text: Theophilus to Autolycus.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 1:2
verses.text: Book 3   Chapter I.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 1:3
verses.text: —Autolycus Not Yet Convinced.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 1:4
verses.text: Theophilus to Autolycus, greeting: Seeing that writers are fond of composing a multitude of books for vainglory,—some concerning gods, and wars, and chronology, and some, too, concerning useless legends, and other such labour in vain, in which you also have been used to employ yourself until now, and do not grudge to endure that toil; but though you conversed with me, are still of opinion that the word of truth is an idle tale, and suppose that our writings are recent and modern;—on this account I also will not grudge the labour of compendiously setting forth to you, God helping me, the antiquity of our books, reminding you of it in few words, that you may not grudge the labour of reading it, but may recognise the folly of the other authors.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—Profane Authors Had No Means of Knowing the Truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 2:2
verses.text: For it was fit that they who wrote should themselves have been eye-witnesses of those things concerning which they made assertions, or should accurately have ascertained them from those who had seen them; for they who write of things unascertained beat the air.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 2:3
verses.text: For what did it profit Homer to have composed the Trojan war, and to have deceived many; or Hesiod, the register of the theogony of those whom he calls gods; or Orpheus, the three hundred and sixty-five gods, whom in the end of his life he rejects, maintaining in his precepts that there is one God? What profit did the sphaerography of the world's circle confer on Aratus, or those who held the same doctrine as he, except glory among men? And not even that did they reap as they deserved.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 2:4
verses.text: And what truth did they utter? Or what good did their tragedies do to Euripides and Sophocles, or the other tragedians? Or their comedies to Menander and Aristophanes, and the other comedians? Or their histories to Herodotus and Thucydides? Or the shrines and the pillars of Hercules to Pythagoras, or the Cynic philosophy to Diogenes? What good did it do Epicurus to maintain that there is no providence; or Empedocles to teach atheism; or Socrates to swear by the dog, and the goose, and the plane-tree, and aesculapius struck by lightning, and the demons whom he invoked? And why did he willingly die? What reward, or of what kind, did he expect to receive after death? What did Plato's system of culture profit him? Or what benefit did the rest of the philosophers derive from their doctrines, not to enumerate the whole of them, since they are numerous? But these things we say, for the purpose of exhibiting their useless and godless opinions.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—Their Contradictions.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:2
verses.text: For all these, having fallen in love with vain and empty reputation, neither themselves knew the truth, nor guided others to the truth: for the things which they said themselves convict them of speaking inconsistently; and most of them demolished their own doctrines.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:3
verses.text: For not only did they refute one another, but some, too, even stultified their own teachings; so that their reputation has issued in shame and folly, for they are condemned by men of understanding.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:4
verses.text: For either they made assertions concerning the gods, and afterwards taught that there was no god; or if they spoke even of the creation of the world, they finally said that all things were produced spontaneously.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:5
verses.text: Yea, and even speaking of providence, they taught again that the world was not ruled by providence.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:6
verses.text: But what? Did they not, when they essayed to write even of honourable conduct, teach the perpetration of lasciviousness, and fornication, and adultery; and did they not introduce hateful and unutterable wickedness? And they proclaim that their gods took the lead in committing unutterable acts of adultery, and in monstrous banquets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:7
verses.text: For who does not sing Saturn devouring his own children, and Jove his son gulping down Metis, and preparing for the gods a horrible feast, at which also they say that Vulcan, a lame blacksmith, did the waiting; and how Jove not only married Juno, his own sister, but also with foul mouth did abominable wickedness? And the rest of his deeds, as many as the poets sing, it is likely you are acquainted with.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 3:8
verses.text: Why need I further recount the deeds of Neptune and Apollo, or Bacchus and Hercules, of the bosom-loving Minerva, and the shameless Venus, since in another place we have given a more accurate account of these?.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—How Autolycus Had Been Misled by False Accusations Against the Christians.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:2
verses.text: Nor indeed was there any necessity for my refuting these, except that I see you still in dubiety about the word of the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:3
verses.text: For though yourself prudent, you endure fools gladly.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:4
verses.text: Otherwise you would not have been moved by senseless men to yield yourself to empty words, and to give credit to the prevalent rumor wherewith godless lips falsely accuse us, who are worshippers of God, and are called Christians, alleging that the wives of us all are held in common and made promiscuous use of; and that we even commit incest with our own sisters, and, what is most impious and barbarous of all, that we eat human flesh.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:5
verses.text: But further, they say that our doctrine has but recently come to light, and that we have nothing to allege in proof of what we receive as truth, nor of our teaching, but that our doctrine is foolishness.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:6
verses.text: I wonder, then, chiefly that you, who in other matters are studious, and a scrutinizer of all things, give but a careless hearing to us.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 4:7
verses.text: For, if it were possible for you, you would not grudge to spend the night in the libraries.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—Philosophers Inculcate Cannibalism.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 5:2
verses.text: Since, then, you have read much, what is your opinion of the precepts of Zeno, and Diogenes, and Cleanthes, which their books contain, inculcating the eating of human flesh: that fathers be cooked and eaten by their own children; and that if any one refuse or reject a part of this infamous food, he himself be devoured who will riot eat? An utterance even more godless than these is found,—that, namely, of Diogenes, who teaches children to bring their own parents in sacrifice, and devour them.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 5:3
verses.text: And does not the historian Herodotus narrate that Cambyses, when he had slaughtered the children of Harpagus, cooked them also, and set them as a meal before their father? And, still further, he narrates that among the Indians the parents are eaten by their own children.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 5:4
verses.text: Oh! the godless teaching of those who recorded, yea, rather, inculcated such things! Oh! their wickedness and godlessness! Oh! the conception of those who thus accurately philosophized, and profess philosophy! For they who taught these doctrines have filled the world with iniquity.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—Other Opinions of the Philosophers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:2
verses.text: And regarding lawless conduct, those who have blindly wandered into the choir of philosophy have, almost to a man, spoken with one voice.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:3
verses.text: Certainly Plato, to mention him first who seems to have been the most respectable philosopher among them, expressly, as it were, legislates in his first book, entitled The Republic, that the wives of all be common, using the precedent of the son of Jupiter and the lawgiver of the Cretans, in order that under this pretext there might be an abundant offspring from the best persons, and that those who were worn with toil might be comforted by such intercourse.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:4
verses.text: And Epicurus himself, too, as well as teaching atheism, teaches along with it incest with mothers and sisters, and this in transgression of the laws which forbid it; for Solon distinctly legislated regarding this, in order that from a married parent children might lawfully spring, that they might not be born of adultery, so that no one should honour as his father him who was not his father, or dishonour him who was really his father, through ignorance that he was so.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:5
verses.text: And these things the other laws of the Romans and Greeks also prohibit.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 6:6
verses.text: Why, then, do Epicurus and the Stoics teach incest and sodomy, with which doctrines they have filled libraries, so that from boyhood this lawless intercourse is learned? And why should I further spend time on them, since even of those they call gods they relate similar things?.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—Varying Doctrine Concerning the Gods.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:2
verses.text: For after they had said that these are gods, they again made them of no account.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:3
verses.text: For  some said that they were composed of atoms; and others, again, that they eventuate in atoms; and they say that the gods have no more power than men.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:4
verses.text: Plato, too, though he says these are gods, would have them composed of matter.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:5
verses.text: And Pythagoras, after he had made such a toil and moil about the gods, and travelled up and down for information, at last determines that all things are produced naturally and spontaneously, and that the gods care nothing for men.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:6
verses.text: And how many atheistic opinions Clitomachus the academician introduced, I need not recount.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:7
verses.text: And did not Critias and Protagoras of Abdera say, "For whether the gods exist, I am not able to affirm concerning them, nor to explain of what nature they are; for there are many things would prevent me"? And to speak of the opinions of the most atheistical, Euhemerus, is superfluous.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:8
verses.text: For having made many daring assertions concerning the gods, he at last would absolutely deny their existence, and have all things to be governed by self-regulated action.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:9
verses.text: And Plato, who spoke so much of the unity of God and of the soul of man, asserting that the soul is immortal, is not he himself afterwards found, inconsistently with himself, to maintain that some souls pass into other men, and that others take their departure into irrational animals? How can his doctrine fail to seem dreadful and monstrous—to those at least who have any judgment—that he who was once a man shall afterwards be a wolf, or a dog, or an ass, or some other irrational brute? Pythagoras, too, is found venting similar nonsense, besides his demolishing providence.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:10
verses.text: Which of them, then, shall we believe? Philemon, the comic poet, who says,—  "Good hope have they who praise and serve the gods;"  or those whom we have mentioned—Euhemerus, and Epicurus, and Pythagoras, and the others who deny that the gods are to be worshipped, and who abolish providence? Concerning God and providence, Ariston said:—  "Be of good courage: God will still preserve And greatly help all those who so deserve.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:11
verses.text: If no promotion waits on faithful men, Say what advantage goodness offers then.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:12
verses.text: 'Tis granted—yet I often see the just Faring but ill, from ev'ry honour thrust; While they whose own advancement is their aim, Oft in this present life have all they claim.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:13
verses.text: But we must look beyond, and wait the end, That consummation to which all things tend.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:14
verses.text: 'Tis not, as vain and wicked men have said, By an unbridled destiny we're led: It is not blinded chance that rules the world, Nor uncontrolled are all things onward hurled.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:15
verses.text: The wicked blinds himself with this belief; But be ye sure, of all rewards, the chief Is still reserved for those who holy live; And Providence to wicked men will give Only the just reward which is their meed, And fitting punishment for each bad deed".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:16
verses.text: And one can see how inconsistent with each other are the things which others, and indeed almost the majority, have said about God and providence.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:17
verses.text: For some have absolutely cancelled God and providence; and others, again, have affirmed God, and have avowed that all things are governed by providence.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:18
verses.text: The intelligent hearer and reader must therefore give minute attention to their expressions; as also Simylus said: "It is the custom of the poets to name by a common designation the surpassingly wicked and the excellent; we therefore must discriminate".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:19
verses.text: As also Philemon says: "A senseless man who sits and merely hears is a troublesome feature; for he does not blame himself, so foolish is he".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 7:20
verses.text: We must then give attention, and consider what is said, critically inquiring into what has been uttered by the philosophers and the poets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—Wickedness Attributed to the Gods by Heathen Writers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:2
verses.text: For, denying that there are gods, they again acknowledge their existence, and they said they committed grossly wicked deeds.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:3
verses.text: And, first, of Jove the poets euphoniously sing the wicked actions.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:4
verses.text: And Chrysippus, who talked a deal of nonsense, is he not found publishing that Juno had the foulest intercourse with Jupiter? For why should I recount the impurities of the so-called mother of the gods, or of Jupiter Latiaris thirsting for human blood, or the castrated Attis; or of Jupiter, surnamed Tragedian, and how he defiled himself, as they say, and now is worshipped among the Romans as a god? I am silent about the temples of Antinous, and of the others whom you call gods.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:5
verses.text: For when related to sensible persons, they excite laughter.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:6
verses.text: They who elaborated such a philosophy regarding either the non-existence of God, or promiscuous intercourse and beastly concubinage, are themselves condemned by their own teachings.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 8:7
verses.text: Moreover, we find from the writings they composed that the eating of human flesh was received among them; and they record that those whom they honour as gods were the first to do these things.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Christian Doctrine of God and His Law.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:2
verses.text: Now we also confess that God exists, but that He is one, the creator, and maker, and fashioner of this universe; and we know that all things are arranged by His providence, but by Him alone.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:3
verses.text: And we have learned a holy law; but we have as lawgiver Him who is really God, who teaches us to act righteously, and to be pious, and to do good.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:4
verses.text: And concerning piety He says, "Thou shalt have no other gods before me.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:5
verses.text: Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of anything that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth: thou shalt not bow down thyself to them, nor serve them: for I am the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:6
verses.text: And of doing good He said: "Honour thy father and thy mother; that it may be well with thee, and that thy days may be long in the land which I the Lord God give thee".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:7
verses.text: Again, concerning righteousness: "Thou shalt not commit adultery.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:8
verses.text: Thou shalt not kill.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:9
verses.text: Thou shalt not steal.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:10
verses.text: Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:11
verses.text: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, nor his land, nor his man-servant, nor his maid-servant, nor his ox, nor his beast of burden, nor any of his cattle, nor anything that is thy neighbour's.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:12
verses.text: Thou shalt not wrest the judgment of the poor in his cause.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:13
verses.text: From every unjust matter keep thee far.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:14
verses.text: The innocent and righteous thou shalt not slay; thou shalt not justify the wicked; and thou shalt not take a gift, for gifts blind the eyes of them that see and pervert righteous words".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:15
verses.text: Of this divine law, then, Moses, who also was God's servant, was made the minister both to all the world, and chiefly to the Hebrews, who were also called Jews, whom an Egyptian king had in ancient days enslaved, and who were the righteous seed of godly and holy men—Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:16
verses.text: God, being mindful of them, and doing marvellous and strange miracles by the hand of Moses, delivered them, and led them out of Egypt, leading them through what is called the desert; whom He also settled again in the land of Canaan, which afterwards was called judaea, and gave them a law, and taught them these things.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 9:17
verses.text: Of this great and wonderful law, which tends to all righteousness, the ten heads are such as we have already rehearsed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Of Humanity to Strangers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 10:2
verses.text: Since therefore they were strangers in the land of Egypt, being by birth Hebrews from the land of Chaldaea,—for at that time, there being a famine, they were obliged to migrate to Egypt for the sake of buying food there, where also for a time they sojourned; and these things befell them in accordance with a prediction of God,—having sojourned, then, in Egypt for  years, when Moses was about to lead them out into the desert, God taught them by the law, saying, "Ye shall not afflict a stranger; for ye know the heart of a stranger: for yourselves were strangers in the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—Of Repentance.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:2
verses.text: And when the people transgressed the law which had been given to them by God, God being good and pitiful, unwilling to destroy them, in addition to His giving them the law, afterwards sent forth also prophets to them from among their brethren, to teach and remind them of the contents of the law, and to turn them to repentance, that they might sin no more.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:3
verses.text: But if they persisted in their wicked deeds, He forewarned them that they should be delivered into subjection to all the kingdoms of the earth; and that this has already happened them is manifest.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:4
verses.text: Concerning repentance, then, Isaiah the prophet, generally indeed to all, but expressly to the people, says: "Seek ye the Lord while He may be found, call ye upon Him while He is near: let the wicked forsake his ways, and the unrighteous man his thoughts: and let him return unto the Lord his God, and he will find mercy, for He will abundantly pardon".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:5
verses.text: And another prophet, Ezekiel, says: "If the wicked will turn from all his sins that he hath committed, and keep all My statutes, and do that which is right in My sight, he shall surely live, he shall not die.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:6
verses.text: All his transgressions that he hath committed, they shall not be mentioned unto him; but in his righteousness that he hath done he shall live: for I desire not the death of the sinner, saith the Lord, but that he turn from his wicked way, and live".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:7
verses.text: Again Isaiah: "Ye who take deep and wicked counsel, turn ye, that ye may be saved".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:8
verses.text: And another prophet, Jeremiah: "Turn to the Lord your God, as a grape-gatherer to his basket, and ye shall find mercy".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 11:9
verses.text: Many therefore, yea rather, countless are the sayings in the Holy Scriptures regarding repentance, God being always desirous that the race of men turn from all their sins.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Of Righteousness.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:2
verses.text: Moreover, concerning the righteousness which the law enjoined, confirmatory utterances are found both with the prophets and in the Gospels, because they all spoke inspired by one Spirit of God.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:3
verses.text: Isaiah accordingly spoke thus: "Put away the evil of your doings from your souls; learn to do well, seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge the fatherless, plead for the widow".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:4
verses.text: And again the same prophet said: "Loose every band of wickedness, dissolve every oppressive contract, let the oppressed go free, and tear up every unrighteous bond.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:5
verses.text: Deal out thy bread to the hungry, and bring the houseless poor to thy home.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:6
verses.text: When thou seest the naked, cover him, and hide not thyself from thine own flesh.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:7
verses.text: Then shall thy light break forth as the morning, and thine health shall spring forth speedily, and thy righteousness shall go before thee".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:8
verses.text: In like manner also Jeremiah says: "Stand in the ways, and see, and ask which is the good way of the Lord your God, and walk in it and ye shall find rest for your souls.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:9
verses.text: Judge just judgment, for in this is the will of the Lord your God".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:10
verses.text: So also says Hosea: "Keep judgment, and draw near to your God, who established the heavens and created the earth".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:11
verses.text: And another, Joel, spoke in agreement with these: "Gather the people, sanctify the congregation, assemble the elders, gather the children that are in arms; let the bridegroom go forth of his chamber, and the bride out of her closet, and pray to the Lord thy God urgently that he may have mercy upon you, and blot out your sins".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 12:12
verses.text: In like manner also another, Zachariah: "Thus saith the Lord Almighty, Execute true judgment, and show mercy and compassion every man to his brother; and oppress not the widow, nor the fatherless, nor the stranger; and let none of you imagine evil against his brother in your heart, saith the Lord Almighty".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Of Chastity.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:2
verses.text: And concerning chastity, the holy word teaches us not only not to sin in act, but not even in thought, not even in the heart to think of any evil, nor look on another man's wife with our eyes to lust after her.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:3
verses.text: Solomon, accordingly, who was a king and a prophet, said: "Let thine eyes look right on, and let thine eyelids look straight before thee: make straight paths for your feet".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:4
verses.text: And the voice of the Gospel teaches still more urgently concerning chastity, saying: "Whosoever looketh on a woman who is not his own wife, to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:5
verses.text: "And he that marrieth," says the Gospel, "her that is divorced from her husband, committeth adultery; and whosoever putteth away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 13:6
verses.text: Because Solomon says: "Can a man take fire in his bosom, and his clothes not be burned? Or can one walk upon hot coals, and his feet not be burned? So he that goeth in to a married woman shall not be innocent".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Of Loving Our Enemies.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:2
verses.text: And that we should be kindly disposed, not only towards those of our own stock, as some suppose, Isaiah the prophet said: "Say to those that hate you, and that cast you out, Ye are our brethren, that the name of the Lord may be glorified, and be apparent in their joy".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:3
verses.text: And the Gospel says: "Love your enemies, and pray for them that despitefully use you.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:4
verses.text: For if ye love them who love you, what reward have ye? This do also the robbers and the publicans".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:5
verses.text: And those that do good it teaches not to boast, lest they become men-pleasers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:6
verses.text: For it says: "Let not your left hand know what your right hand doeth".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:7
verses.text: Moreover, concerning subjection to authorities and powers, and prayer for them, the divine word gives us instructions, in order that "we may lead a quiet and peaceable life".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 14:8
verses.text: And it teaches us to render all things to all, "honour to whom honour, fear to whom fear, tribute to whom tribute; to owe no man anything, but to love all".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—The Innocence of the Christians Defended.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:2
verses.text: Consider, therefore, whether those who teach such things can possibly live indifferently, and be commingled in unlawful intercourse, or, most impious of all, eat human flesh, especially when we are forbidden so much as to witness shows of gladiators, lest we become partakers and abettors of murders.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:3
verses.text: But neither may we see the other spectacles, lest our eyes and ears be defiled, participating in the utterances there sung.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:4
verses.text: For if one should speak of cannibalism, in these spectacles the children of Thyestes and Tereus are eaten; and as for adultery, both in the case of men and of gods, whom they celebrate in elegant language for honours and prizes, this is made the subject of their dramas.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:5
verses.text: But far be it from Christians to conceive any such deeds; for with them temperance dwells, self-restraint is practiced, monogamy is observed, chastity is guarded, iniquity exterminated, sin extirpated, righteousness exercised, law administered, worship performed, God acknowledged: truth governs, grace guards, peace screens them; the holy word guides, wisdom teaches, life directs, God reigns.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 15:6
verses.text: Therefore, though we have much to say regarding our manner of life, and the ordinances of God, the maker of all creation, we yet consider that we have for the present reminded you of enough to induce you to study these things, especially since you can now read our writings for yourself, that as you have been fond of acquiring information, you may still be studious in this direction also.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Uncertain Conjectures of the Philosophers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:2
verses.text: But I wish now to give you a more accurate demonstration, God helping me, of the historical periods, that you may see that our doctrine is not modern nor fabulous, but more ancient and true than all poets and authors who have written in uncertainty.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:3
verses.text: For some, maintaining that the world was uncreated, went into infinity; and others, asserting that it was created, said that already , years had passed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:4
verses.text: This is stated by Apollonius the Egyptian.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:5
verses.text: And Plato, who is esteemed to have been the wisest of the Greeks, into what nonsense did he run? For in his book entitled The Republic, we find him expressly saying: "For if things had in all time remained in their present arrangement, when ever could any new thing be discovered? For ten thousand times ten thousand years elapsed without record, and one thousand or twice as many years have gone by since some things were discovered by Daedalus, and some by Orpheus, and some by Palamedes".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:6
verses.text: And when he says that these things happened, he implies that ten thousand times ten thousand years elapsed from the flood to Daedalus.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:7
verses.text: And after he has said a great deal about the cities of the world, and the settlements, and the nations, he owns that he has said these things conjecturally.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:8
verses.text: For he says, "If then, my friend, some god should promise us, that if we attempted to make a survey of legislation, the things now said," etc.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 16:9
verses.text: , which shows that he was speaking by guess; and if by guess, then what he says is not true.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—Accurate Information of the Christians.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 17:2
verses.text: It behoved, therefore, that he should the rather become a scholar of God in this matter of legislation, as he himself confessed that in no other way could he gain accurate information than by God's teaching him through the law.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 17:3
verses.text: And did not the poets Homer and Hesiod and Orpheus profess that they themselves had been instructed by Divine Providence? Moreover, it is said that among your writers there were prophets and prognosticators, and that those wrote accurately who were informed by them.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 17:4
verses.text: How much more, then, shall we know the truth who are instructed by the holy prophets, who were possessed by the Holy Spirit of God! On this account all the prophets spoke harmoniously and in agreement with one another, and foretold the things that would come to pass in all the world.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 17:5
verses.text: For the very accomplishment of predicted and already consummated events should demonstrate to those who are fond of information, yea rather, who are lovers of truth, that those things are really true which they declared concerning the epochs and eras before the deluge: to wit, how the years have run on since the world was created until now, so as to manifest the ridiculous mendacity of your authors, and show that their statements are not true.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—Errors of the Greeks About the Deluge.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:2
verses.text: For Plato, as we said above, when he had demonstrated that a deluge had happened, said that it extended not over the whole earth, but only over the plains, and that those who fled to the highest hills saved themselves.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:3
verses.text: But others say that there existed Deucalion and Pyrrha, and that they were preserved in a chest; and that Deucalion, after he came out of the chest, flung stones behind him, and that men were produced from the stones; from which circumstance they say that men in the mass are named "people".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:4
verses.text: Others, again, say that Clymenus existed in a second flood.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:5
verses.text: From what has already been said, it is evident that they who wrote such things and philosophized to so little purpose are miserable, and very profane and senseless persons.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 18:6
verses.text: But Moses, our prophet and the servant of God, in giving an account of the genesis of the world, related in what manner the flood came upon the earth, telling us, besides, how the details of the flood came about, and relating no fable of Pyrrha nor of Deucalion or Clymenus; nor, forsooth, that only the plains were submerged, and that those only who escaped to the mountains were saved.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19—Accurate Account of the Deluge.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:2
verses.text: And neither does he make out that there was a second flood: on the contrary, he said that never again would there be a flood of water on the world; as neither indeed has there been, nor ever shall be.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:3
verses.text: And he says that eight human beings were preserved in the ark, in that which had been prepared by God's direction, not by Deucalion, but by Noah; which Hebrew word means in English "rest," as we have elsewhere shown that Noah, when he announced to the men then alive that there was a flood coming, prophesied to them, saying, Come thither, God calls you to repentance.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:4
verses.text: On this account he was fitly called Deucalion.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:5

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:6

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:7

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:8

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:9
verses.text: And thus the race of all the men that then were was destroyed, and those only who were protected in the ark were saved; and these, we have already said, were eight.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:10
verses.text: And of the ark, the remains are to this day to be seen in the Arabian mountains.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 19:11
verses.text: This, then, is in sum the history of the deluge.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—Prophets More Ancient Than Greek Writers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:2
verses.text: So then let what has been said suffice for the testimony of the Phoenicians and Egyptians, and for the account of our chronology given by the writers Manetho the Egyptian, and Menander the Ephesian, and also Josephus, who wrote the Jewish war, which they waged with the Romans.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:3
verses.text: For from these very old records it is proved that the writings of the rest are more recent than the writings given to us through Moses, yes, and than the subsequent prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:4
verses.text: For the last of the prophets, who was called Zechariah, was contemporary with the reign of Darius.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:5
verses.text: But even the lawgivers themselves are all found to have legislated subsequently to that period.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:6
verses.text: For if one were to mention Solon the Athenian, he lived in the days of the kings Cyrus and Darius, in the time of the prophet Zechariah first mentioned, who was by many years the last of the prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:7
verses.text: Or if you mention the lawgivers Lycurgus, or Draco, or Minos, Josephus tells us in his writings that the sacred books take precedence of them in antiquity, since even before the reign of Jupiter over the Cretans, and before the Trojan war, the writings of the divine law which has been given to us through Moses were in existence.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 23:8
verses.text: And that we may give a more accurate exhibition of eras and dates, we will, God helping us, now give an account not only of the dates after the deluge, but also of those before it, so as to reckon the whole number of all the years, as far as possible; tracing up to the very beginning of the creation of the world, which Moses the servant of God recorded through the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:4
verses.text: And after these kings Solomon reigned, who also, by the will of God, was the first to build the temple in Jerusalem; he reigned  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:5
verses.text: And after him Rehoboam,  years; and after him Abias,  years; and after him Asa,  years; and after him Jehoshaphat,  years; and after him Joram,  years; and after him Ahaziah,  year; and after him Athaliah,  years; and after her Josiah,  years; and after him Amaziah,  years; and after him Uzziah,  years; and after him Jotham,  years; and after him Ahaz,  years; and after him Hezekiah,  years; and after him Manasseh,  years; and after him Amon,  years; and after him Josiah,  years; and after him Jehoahaz,  months; and after him Jehoiakim,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:6
verses.text: Then another Jehoiakim,  months  days; and after him Zedekiah,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:7
verses.text: And after these kings, the people, continuing in their sins, and not repenting, the king of Babylon, named Nebuchadnezzar, came up into Judaea, according to the prophecy of Jeremiah.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:8
verses.text: He transferred the people of the Jews to Babylon, and destroyed the temple which Solomon had built.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:9
verses.text: And in the Babylonian banishment the people passed  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:10
verses.text: Until the sojourning in the land of Babylon, there are therefore, in all,  years  months and  days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:11
verses.text: And according as God had, by the prophet Jeremiah, foretold that the people should be led captive to Babylon, in like manner He signified beforehand that they should also return into their own land after  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:12
verses.text: These  years then being accomplished, Cyrus becomes king of the Persians, who, according to the prophecy of Jeremiah, issued a decree in the second year of his reign, enjoining by his edict that all Jews who were in his kingdom should return to their own country, and rebuild their temple to God, which the fore-mentioned king of Babylon had demolished.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:13
verses.text: Moreover, Cyrus, in compliance with the instructions of God, gave orders to his own bodyguards, Sabessar and Mithridates, that the vessels which had been taken out of the temple of Judaea by Nebuchadnezzar should be restored, and placed again in the temple.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 25:14
verses.text: In the second year, therefore, of Darius are fulfilled the  years which were foretold by Jeremiah.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 26—Contrast Between Hebrew and Greek Writings.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 26:2
verses.text: Hence one can see how our sacred writings are shown to be more ancient and true than those of the Greeks and Egyptians, or any other historians.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 26:3
verses.text: For Herodotus and Thucydides, as also Xenophon, and most other historians, began their relations from about the reign of Cyrus and Darius, not being able to speak with accuracy of prior and ancient times.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 26:4
verses.text: For what great matters did they disclose if they spoke of Darius and Cyrus, barbarian kings, or of the Greeks Zopyrus and Hippias, or of the wars of the Athenians and Lacedaemonians, or the deeds of Xerxes or of Pausanias, who ran the risk of starving to death in the temple of Minerva, or the history of Themistocles and the Peloponnesian war, or of Alcibiades and Thrasybulus? For my purpose is not to furnish mere matter of much talk, but to throw light upon the number of years from the foundation of the world, and to condemn the empty labour and trifling of these authors, because there have neither been twenty thousand times ten thousand years from the flood to the present time, as Plato said, affirming that there had been so many years; nor yet  times , years, as we have already mentioned Apollonius the Egyptian gave out; nor is the world uncreated, nor is there a spontaneous production of all things, as Pythagoras and the rest dreamed; but, being indeed created, it is also governed by the providence of God, who made all things; and the whole course of time and the years are made plain to those who wish to obey the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 26:5
verses.text: Lest, then, I seem to have made things plain up to the time of Cyrus, and to neglect the subsequent periods, as if through inability to exhibit them, I will endeavour, by God's help, to give an account, according to my ability, of the course of the subsequent times.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 27—Roman Chronology to the Death of M.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:2
verses.text: Aurelius.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:3
verses.text: When Cyrus, then, had reigned twenty-nine years, and had been slain by Tomyris in the country of the Massagetae, this being in the d Olympiad, then the Romans began to increase in power, God strengthening them, Rome having been founded by Romulus, the reputed child of Mars and Ilia, in the th Olympiad, on the st day of April, the year being then reckoned as consisting of ten months.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:4
verses.text: Cyrus, then, having died, as we have already said, in the d Olympiad, this date falls  A.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:5
verses.text: U.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:6
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:7
verses.text: , in which year also Tarquinius, surnamed Superbus, reigned over the Romans, who was the first who banished Romans and corrupted the youth, and made eunuchs of the citizens, and, moreover, first defiled virgins, and then gave them in marriage.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:8
verses.text: On this account he was fitly called Superbus in the Roman language, and that is translated "the Proud".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:9
verses.text: For he first decreed that those who saluted him should have their salute acknowledged by some one else.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:10
verses.text: He reigned twenty-five years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:11
verses.text: After him yearly consuls were introduced, tribunes also and ediles for  years, whose names we consider it long and superfluous to recount.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:12
verses.text: For if any one is anxious to learn them, he will ascertain them from the tables which Chryserus the nomenclator compiled: he was a freedman of Aurelius Verus, who composed a very lucid record of all things, both names and dates, from the rounding of Rome to the death of his own patron, the Emperor Verus.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:13
verses.text: The annual magistrates ruled the Romans, as we say, for  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:14
verses.text: Afterwards those who are called emperors began in this order: first, Caius Julius, who reigned  years  months  days; then Augustus,  years  months  day; Tiberius,  years; then another Caius,  years  months  days; Claudius,  years  months  days; Nero,  years  months  days; Galba,  years  months  days; Otho,  months  days; Vitellius,  months  days; Vespasian,  years  months  days; Titus,  years  days; Domitian,  years  months  days; Nerva,  year  months  days; Trajan,  years  months  days; Adrian,  years  months  days; Antoninus,  years  months  days; Verus,  years  days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:15
verses.text: The time therefore of the Caesars to the death of the Emperor Verus is  years  days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 27:16
verses.text: From the death of Cyrus, therefore, and the reign of Tarquinius Superbus, to the death of the Emperor Verus, the whole time amounts to  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 28—Leading Chronological Epochs.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:2
verses.text: And from the foundation of the world the whole time is thus traced, so far as its main epochs are concerned.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:3
verses.text: From the creation of the world to the deluge were  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:4
verses.text: And from the deluge to the time when Abraham our forefather begat a son,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:5
verses.text: And from Isaac, Abraham's son, to the time when the people dwelt with Moses in the desert,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:6
verses.text: And from the death of Moses and the rule of Joshua the son of Nun, to the death of the patriarch David,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:7
verses.text: And from the death of David and the reign of Solomon to the sojourning of the people in the land of Babylon,  years  months  days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:8
verses.text: And from the government of Cyrus to the death of the Emperor Aurelius Verus,  years.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 28:9
verses.text: All the years from the creation of the world amount to a total of  years, and the odd months and days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 29—Antiquity of Christianity.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:2
verses.text: These periods, then, and all the above-mentioned facts, being viewed collectively, one can see the antiquity of the prophetical writings and the divinity of our doctrine, that the doctrine is not recent, nor our tenets mythical and false, as some think; but very ancient and true.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:3
verses.text: For Thallus mentioned Belus, king of the Assyrians, and Saturn, son of Titan, alleging that Belus with the Titans made war against Jupiter and the so-called gods in his alliance; and on this occasion he says that Gyges, being defeated, fled to Tartessus.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:4
verses.text: At that time Gyges ruled over that country, which then was called Acte, but now is named Attica.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:5
verses.text: And whence the other countries and cities derived their names, we think it unnecessary to recount, especially to you who are acquainted with history.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:6
verses.text: That Moses, and not he only, but also most of the prophets who followed him, is proved to be older than all writers, and than Saturn and Belus and the Trojan war, is manifest.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:7
verses.text: For according to the history of Thallus, Belus is found to be  years prior to the Trojan war.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:8
verses.text: But we have shown above that Moses lived somewhere about  or  years before the sack of Troy.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:9
verses.text: And as Saturn and Belus flourished at the same time, most people do not know which is Saturn and which is Belus.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:10
verses.text: Some worship Saturn, and call him Bel or Bal, especially the inhabitants of the eastern countries, for they do not know who either Saturn or Belus is.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:11
verses.text: And among the Romans he is called Saturn, for neither do they know which of the two is more ancient—Saturn or Bel.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:12
verses.text: So far as regards the commencement of the Olympiads, they say that the observance dates from Iphitus, but according to others from Linus, who is also called Ilius.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:13
verses.text: The order which the whole number of years and Olympiads holds, we have shown above.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:14
verses.text: I think I have now, according to my ability, accurately discoursed both of the godlessness of your practices, and of the whole number of the epochs of history.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:15
verses.text: For if even a chronological error has been committed by us, of, e.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:16
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:17
verses.text: ,  or , or even  years, yet not of thousands and tens of thousands, as Plato and Apollonius and other mendacious authors have hitherto written.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:18
verses.text: And perhaps our knowledge of the whole number of the years is not quite accurate, because the odd months and days are not set down in the sacred books.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:19
verses.text: But so far as regards the periods we speak of, we are corroborated by Berosus, the Chaldaean philosopher, who made the Greeks acquainted with the Chaldaean literature, and uttered some things concerning the deluge, and many other points of history, in agreement with Moses; and with the prophets Jeremiah and Daniel also, he spoke in a measure of agreement.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:20
verses.text: For he mentioned what happened to the Jews under the king of the Babylonians, whom he calls Abobassor, and who is called by the Hebrews Nebuchadnezzar.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 29:21
verses.text: And he also spoke of the temple of Jerusalem; how it was desolated by the king of the Chaldaeans, and that the foundations of the temple having been laid the second year of the reign of Cyrus, the temple was completed in the second year of the reign of Darius.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30—Why the Greeks Did Not Mention Our Histories.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:2
verses.text: But the Greeks make no mention of the histories which give the truth: first, because they themselves only recently became partakers of the knowledge of letters; and they themselves own it, alleging that letters were invented, some say among the Chaldaeans, and others with the Egyptians, and others again say that they are derived from the Phoenicians.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:3
verses.text: And secondly, because they sinned, and still sin, in not making mention of God, but of vain and useless matters.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:4
verses.text: For thus they most heartily celebrate Homer and Hesiod, and the rest of the poets, but the glory of the incorruptible and only God they not only omit to mention, but blaspheme; yes, and they persecuted, and do daily persecute, those who worship Him.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:5
verses.text: And not only so, but they even bestow prizes and honours on those who in harmonious language insult God; but of those who are zealous in the pursuit of virtue and practice a holy life, some they stoned, some they put to death, and up to the present time they subject them to savage tortures.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:6
verses.text: Wherefore such men have necessarily lost the wisdom of God, and have not found the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book III 30:7
verses.text: If you please, then, study these things carefully, that you may have a compendium and pledge of the truth.
